block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Peru's President Calls For Immediate Elections President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru announced that he would call an immediate new general election and that he would not run for re-election. He made a televised address amid an escalating corruption scandal involving the head of his spy service.
INTERNATIONAL

Peru's President Calls For Immediate Elections President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru announced that he would call an immediate new general election and that he would not run for re-election. He made a televised address amid an escalating corruption scandal involving the head of his spy service.

A Plan for Debt Relief Financial leaders of rich nations are planning to announce they will double the number of poor nations granted debt relief by year's end at the annual meeting of international lending agencies in Prague next week.

Camp David Account Published A first-hand account of this summer's Camp David summit meeting printed in a Palestinian newspaper included statements from the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, indicating that he feared for his life if he deviated from demands for Palestinian control of a major site.

Swiss Vote on Immigration The Swiss will vote on whether to restrict foreigners to 18 percent of their population. The government, worried about further damaging Switzerland's image, is lobbying strongly against the measure.

Venezuelan Border Dispute President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela has revived a long-dormant border dispute with Guyana, after Guyana's decision to allow an American company to build a satellite-launching center in territory that Venezuela claims as its own.

Assassination in Indonesia A leading candidate for governor of Indonesia's troubled Aceh province, a prominent Islamic university rector who has opposed use of the military to resolve a separatist issue, was assassinated.
NATIONAL

Bush and Gore Focus On 10 Crucial States Vice President Al Gore, who has erased Gov. George W. Bush's lead in most national polls, has also edged ahead of him in the battle for electoral votes, according to independent and partisan analysts. But several major states are still tossups.
The candidates' budget proposals appear to be more substantive than those in previous elections, experts say, but each plan hinges on optimistic assumptions.
Mr. Bush attacked Mr. Gore's positions on tax cuts, Medicare and education, signaling his campaign's desire to focus on issues.
Both campaigns agreed on the formats of three presidential debates in October and selected Jim Lehrer of PBS to moderate them.
In California, Representative James E. Rogan and his Democratic challenger, State Senator Adam Schiff, are in a bitter contest, the nation's most expensive House race.
Foundation Is Out of Money The Barnes Foundation near Philadelphia has depleted its endowment, leaving it without money to care for its revered art collection.
Unions Turn to Celebrities Two unions representing 135,000 actors striking against the advertising industry have enlisted the support of well-known actors.
More Aid for Elderly Care President Clinton asked Congress to provide $1 billion in grants to help nursing homes hire and train more nurses and nurses' aides.
Scientists Honored Two scientists whose work helped decrease the risk of transmitting hepatitis through blood transfusions are among six winners of the Albert Lasker medical research awards.
NEW YORK/REGION

Bottled Water Complaints Rise Steeply in City and Region The number of complaints of possibly contaminated bottled water rose to 22, and detectives and F.B.I. agents were investigating whether three people who said they had consumed tainted water had made false reports to the authorities, officials said.

Apollo Renewal Languishes It has been a year since Representative Charles B. Rangel agreed to step down as chairman of the nonprofit organization that runs the Apollo Theater and turn over control of the storied Harlem landmark to Time Warner. Yet despite the new leadership, efforts to refurbish the theater have not yet borne fruit. Time Warner executives say they intend to refurbish the Apollo next year.

Nassau Plan Would Raise Taxes Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta submitted a four-year budget plan that would raise property taxes by 4 percent next year and 3 percent each of the following three years. Mr. Gulotta, whose rote resistance to raising property taxes helped bring the county to the edge of fiscal ruin, beat a state-imposed deadline for him to submit a four-year budget plan by a mere two minutes.

Mayor Makes It to Parade Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, disregarding predictions that he would take the weekend off, marched briskly 23 blocks up Fifth Avenue during the Stuben Day parade. The only sign that he had had radioactive seeds implanted in his prostate gland was that he stayed away from children.
OBITUARIES

Elizabeth Gordon The influential editor of House Beautiful magazine for more than 20 years, she was 94. Her magazine issues in the late 1940's explained trends in design to an audience just learning how to consume.
